title: PS4 system update 7.00 allows remote play on Android, doubles party sizes
text:
A party-sized update

The next major update for PlayStation 4 will be out later this week and will allow you to play remotely on any Android device.

You’ll soon be able to stream select PlayStation 4 games on any Android smartphone or tablet running Android 5.0 or higher, as Sony prepares to update its Remote Play App.

There isn’t a specific release date for the version 7.00 update but the PlayStation Blog is promising that it’ll be ‘later this week’.

The update will also allow iOS to display the controller at all times and lock the screen orientation, so there’s no danger of it switching round when you’re playing.

Chat transcriptions are only for America

Both iOS and Android will also be to use a DualShock 4 controller, although for that you’ll need Android 10, iOS 13, iPadOS 13, or macOS Catalina.

The other big change is that that maximum number of people in a party has been increased from eight to 16, allowing you to band together for a game or just to chat in general.

Sony are also promising better connectivity and audio quality, although the new chat transcriptions feature is only for the U.S. – probably because it only works in American English.

The update has been in beta since July, which should hopefully mean that when it does launch for everyone there won’t be any problems.
